newsitem.title: USA: Oklahoma bomb witness wrong about second suspect.
newsitem.headline: Oklahoma bomb witness wrong about second suspect.

text.p: A witness in the Oklahoma City bombing case who prompted police to search for a suspect they were never able to find, now says he was wrong, prosecutors disclosed on Wednesday.
In a statement filed to the court, prosecutors said the witness "would testify that his description of John Doe No. 2 was in error."

They asked the U.S. District Court to deny a defence motion to have the witness's testimony thrown out, and said the witness's confusion should only affect the weight of his testimony, not its admissibility.
Authorities originally said they believed John Doe No. 2 accompanied Timothy McVeigh in renting the Ryder truck used to bomb the Alfred P. Murrah federal building in April 1995.

McVeigh and former army buddy Terry Nichols have been charged in the bombing that killed 168 people. The two will be tried separately, with McVeigh's trail starting on March 31. A date has not been set for Nichols' trial.
Tom Kessinger, a mechanic at the rental agency, changed his mind two months ago when he met with prosecutors and two Federal Bureau of Investigation agents, the filing said.
"Kessinger now is confident that he had Todd Bunting in mind when he provided the description for the John Doe No. 2 composite," prosecutors wrote.
Prosecutors said Kessinger would now testify that a man named Bunting rented a truck the day after McVeigh allegedly did and that Kessinger confused them.
Prosecutors contend McVeigh rented the truck under the alias Robert Kling.
"Kessinger is now unsure whether a second individual accompanied 'Kling' and he has no recall about what any such person might look like," prosecutors said.
However, Kessinger's new account may not put to rest the possibilty of a John Doe No. 2.
Two other employees at the rental store "continue to believe that two men came in to rent the truck on April 17," prosecutors said in their filing.

Earlier, the trial judge chose a Federal Aviation Administration building in Oklahoma City, which can seat at least 300 people, as the site for a closed-circuit telecast of the proceedings for victims of the blast because it can accommodate more people than a courtroom.

But U.S. District Court Judge Richard Matsch denied a request from media in Oklahoma City to attend the closed-circuit telecast. The judge said the law did not provide for news organisations to view the telecast, only victims.
A recently enacted law on terrorism provides for such a telecast when a trial has been moved to another city.
